description: Designed for students who have had limited prior exposure to some form of Chinese (Mandarin or other dialects), but inadequate to advance to the intermediate level.
name: INTEN MOD CHINESE III&IV

values.comments:
This course is a continuation of CHIN021, which is the Intensive Beginning Modern Chinese. The main objective of the course is to help students build a solid foundation of the four basic skills--listening, speaking, reading, and writing Chinese. Grammatical and cultural related issues are discussed during lecture hours. Oral communication tasks are given every week.

The general sentiment of the students about the course design was that it was “hard, but extremely rewarding.” Although students were given a lot of in-class work and assignments, they thought the materials were presented in a way such that they learned a lot of material without feeling too “pushed.”

Students stated that there was “a little bit of discrepancy between what the two teachers taught.” This course was co-taught by Professor Lee and Professor Chen. The difference was reflected in who was grading the tests and homework assignments. Students stated that Professor Lee “cared so much about the students,” and that “it killed him when even one student in class was upset or did not understand the material.”

This course is designed for students who took CHIN021, or for students who have had limited prior exposure to some form of Chinese, but inadequate to advance to the intermediate level. This course, with the prerequisite course CHIN021, allows the students to fulfill their language requirement in a single year instead of two.

This course is a continuation of CHIN021, which is the Intensive Beginning Modern Chinese. The main objective of the course is to help students build a solid foundation of the four basic skills--listening, speaking, reading, and writing Chinese. Grammatical and cultural related issues are discussed during lecture hours. Oral communication tasks are given every week.

The general sentiment of the students about the course design was that it was “hard, but extremely rewarding.” Although students were given a lot of in-class work and assignments, they thought the materials were presented in a way such that they learned a lot of material without feeling too “pushed.”

Students stated that there was “a little bit of discrepancy between what the two teachers taught.” This course was co-taught by Professor Lee and Professor Chen. The difference was reflected in who was grading the tests and homework assignments. One student stated that “Chen Laoshi came off a bit strongly for a newcomer to this class.” Despite her strict style, however, both teachers taught the class very well, making sure that every student was not falling behind.

This course is designed for students who took CHIN021, or for students who have had limited prior exposure to some form of Chinese, but inadequate to advance to the intermediate level. This course, with the prerequisite course CHIN021, allows the students to fulfill their language requirement in a single year instead of two.
